owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: The amount of muscovite and garnet increases, and grain size decreases, towards the eastern and southern pluton borders. contain rounded grains of quartz visible to the naked eye. Most samples are equigranular. Phases are not mapped separately

medium- to coarse-grained granite consists of quartz, K-feldspar, plagioclase and biotite. Apatite, ilmenite, zircon, muscovite and, locally, garnet are accessory minerals; contains rounded grains of quartz visible to the naked eye. Most samples are equigranular
Large xenoliths and roof pendants of country rocks occur mainly in the central part of the intrusion

medium- to coarse-grained granite, consists of quartz, K-feldspar, plagioclase and biotite. Apatite, ilmenite, zircon, muscovite and, locally, garnet are accessory minerals. The amount of muscovite and garnet increases, and grain size decreases, towards the eastern and southern pluton borders. but most samples are equigranular. Both textural types contain rounded grains of quartz visible to the naked eye, pointing to the lack of solid-state deformation. Large xenoliths and roofpendants of country rocks occur mainly in the central part of the intrusion and enclaves of basic igneous rocks in its eastern part.
owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:label: La Tojiza Pluton

rdf:Description.rdfs:comment: considered to have developed exclusively in the magmatic state
rdf:Description.rdfs:label: weak preferred orientation of feldspar and biotite;

owl:NamedIndividual.rdfs:comment: Some outcrops show porphyritic textures with euhedral, 1–5 cm, K-feldspar phenocrysts within a medium- to coarse-grained matrix; contains rounded grains of quartz visible to the naked eye

rdf:Description.terms:source: An example of low-Th/U zircon overgrowths of magmatic origin in a late orogenic Variscan intrusion: the San Ciprián massif (NW Spain) Lopez-Sanchez,Marco A. et al. Journal of the Geological Society(2016),173(2):282 http://dx.doi.org/10.1144/jgs2015-071

U-Pb interpreted date from zircon mantles, interpreted as age of magmatic crystallization. NOTE that this age is younger that the reported age for La Tojiza granite (295 Ma) which is reported to intrude San Ciprian Granite
